surface_pressure.doc: atmospheric pressure, i.e. pressure at ice surface

latent_heat_of_fusion.doc: latent heat of fusion for water [\ref AschwandenBlatter]

specific_heat_capacity.doc: water specific heat capacity at melting point

Mx.doc: Number of grid points in the x direction

My.doc: Number of grid points in the y direction

Mz.doc: Number of grid points in the vertical direction (in the ice)

Mbz.doc: Number of grid points in the vertical direction (in the bedrock thermal layer)

Lbz.doc: thickness of the bedrock thermal layer

Lx.doc: half-width of the computational domain in the x direction

Ly.doc: half-width of the computational domain in the y direction

Lz.doc: height of the computational domain (i.e. maximum ice thickness)

periodicity.doc: grid periodicity; affects the computation of the grid spacing

Schoof_regularizing_velocity.doc: Regularizing velocity (Schoof definition) in the effective viscosity computation

Schoof_regularizing_length.doc: Regularizing length (Schoof definition) in the effective viscosity computation

water_fraction_observed_limit.doc: maximum value of liquid water fraction omega for which softness values are parameterized by [\ref LliboutryDuval1985]; used in Glen-Paterson-Budd-Lliboutry-Duval flow law; compare [\ref AschwandenBuelerKhroulevBlatter]

water_fraction_coefficient.doc: coefficient in Glen-Paterson-Budd flow law for extra dependence of softness on liquid water fraction (omega) [\ref GreveBlatter2009, \ref LliboutryDuval1985]

A.doc: A_Hooke = (1/B_0)^n where n=3 and B_0 = 1.928 a^(1/3) Pa

exponent.comment: FIXME: I'm not sure this belongs here

ice_grain_size.doc: Default constant ice grain size to use with the Goldsby-Kohlstedt [\ref GoldsbyKohlstedt] flow law

compute_grain_size_using_age.doc: Use age of the ice to compute grain size

q.doc: The exponent of the pseudo-plastic basal resistance model

plastic_regularization.doc: this is the second \f$\epsilon\f$ in formula (4.1) in [\ref SchoofStream]
plastic_regularization.units: Set the value of \f$\epsilon\f$ regularization of plastic till

till_c_0.doc: cohesion of till; note Schoof uses zero but Paterson pp 168--169 gives range 0--40 kPa; but Paterson notes that '... all the pairs c_0 and phi in the table would give a yield stress for Ice Stream B that exceeds the basal shear stress there...'

default_till_phi.doc: fill value for till friction angle

high_tauc.doc: the 'high' yield stress value used in two cases: 1) (default): in grounded ice-free areas and 2) in \b all grounded areas if -ssa_floating_only is set.

default_tauc.doc: fill value for yield stress for basal till (plastic or pseudo-plastic model); note 2 x 10^5 Pa = 2.0 bar is quite strong and little sliding should occur without an explicit tauc choice altering this default

minimum_temperature.doc: This is less than water melting point temperature. If ice base is above this value then decide to do SIA sliding, if that mechanism is active at all.

mu_sliding.doc: The sliding law parameter in SIA sliding paradigm. *This kind of sliding is not recommended, which is why it is used in IceEISModel and IceCompModel only. Changing this parameter will not affect regular PISM runs.*  See Appendix B of [\ref BBssasliding] for the dangers in this mechanism.

test_E_mode.doc: Sliding parameters for the verification test E

strength_extension.doc: strength extension used to preserve the ellipticity of the SSA system

constant_nuH.doc: The SSA is made elliptic by use of a constant value for the product of viscosity (nu) and thickness (H).  This value for nu comes from hardness (bar B)=1.9e8 Pa s^(1/3) [\ref MacAyealetal] and a typical strain rate of 0.001 year-1:  nu = (bar B) / (2 * 0.001^(2/3)).  Compare the value of 9.45e14 Pa s = 30 MPa yr in [\ref Ritzetal2001].

min_thickness.doc: The SSA is made elliptic by use of a constant value for the product of viscosity (nu) and thickness (H).  At ice thicknesses below this value the product nu*H switches from the normal vertical integral to a constant value.  The geometry itself is not affected by this value.

nuH_regularization.doc: Initial amount of regularization in computation of product of effective viscosity and thickness (nu * H).  This default value for nu * H comes e.g. from a hardness for the Ross ice shelf (bar B) = 1.9e8 Pa s^(1/3) [\ref MacAyealetal] and a typical strain rate of 0.001 year-1 for the Ross ice shelf, giving nu = (bar B) / (2 * 0.001^(2/3)) = 9.49e+14 Pa s ~~ 30 MPa yr, the value in [\ref Ritzetal2001], but with a tiny thickness H of about 1 cm.

flow_law.doc: The flow law used by the SSA stress balance model.

method.doc: Algorithm for computing the SSA solution.

use_when_grounded.doc: use SSA as a sliding law for grounded ice

max_iterations.doc: Maximum number of iterations for the ice viscosity computation, in the SSAFD object

relative_convergence.doc: Relative change tolerance for the effective viscosity in the SSAFD object

calving_front_stress_boundary_condition.doc: Apply CFBC condition as in [\ref Albrechtetal2011, \ref Winkelmannetal2011].  May only apply to some stress balances; e.g. SSAFD as of May 2011.  If not set then a strength-extension is used, as in [\ref BBssasliding].

write_system_to_matlab.doc: write the SSAFD system to a MATLAB file

use_constant_nuH.doc: Compute velocities in ice shelves and streams with a constant value for the product of viscosity \f$\nu\f$ and thickness \f$H\f$, obtained from the shelf extension

dirichlet_bc.doc: apply SSA velocity Dirichlet boundary condition

Mz.doc: number of vertical levels to use in the Blatter model

enhancement_factor.doc: Flow enhancement factor for the Blatter stress balance flow law

flow_law.doc: The flow law used by the Blatter-Pattyn stress balance model.

bed_smoother.doc: bed smoother (for the bed roughness parameterization)

range.doc: half-width of smoothing domain for PISMBedSmoother, in implementing [\ref Schoofbasaltopg2003] bed roughness parameterization for SIA; set value to zero to turn off mechanism

e_age_coupling.doc: Couple the SIA enhancement factor to age as in [\ref Greve].

flow_law.doc: The flow law used by the SIA stress balance model (modifier).

mantle_viscosity.doc: half-space (mantle) viscosity used by the bed deformation model. See [\ref LingleClark, \ref BLKfastearth]

lithosphere_flexural_rigidity.doc: lithosphere flexural rigidity used by the bed deformation model. See [\ref LingleClark, \ref BLKfastearth]

lithosphere_density.doc: lithosphere density used by the bed deformation model. See [\ref LingleClark, \ref BLKfastearth]

K.doc: Proportionality constant to determine calving rate from strain rates.  Note references [ef Levermannetal2012, ef Martinetal2011] use K in range 10^9 to 3 x 10^11 m a, that is, 3 x 10^16 to 10^19 m s

CFL.doc: apply CFL criterion for eigen-calving rate front retreat

thickness.doc: ad hoc calving at certain threshold for terminal ice thickness

threshold.doc: When terminal ice thickness of floating ice shelf is less than this threshold, it will be calved off

ocean_kill.doc: If used with input from a NetCDF initialization file which has ice-free ocean mask, will zero out ice thicknesses in areas that were ice-free ocean at time zero. This is calving at the location of the original calving front.

floating_ice_killed.doc: If ice is (or becomes) floating then it is set to thickness zero. This is calving at the grounding line.

null_strip_width.doc: if negative then mechanism is inactive; width of strip around computational domain in which water velocity and water amount are set to zero; used by PISMRoutingHydrology and PISMDistributedHydrology

maximum_time_step.doc: maximum allowed time step length used by PISMRoutingHydrology and PISMDistributedHydrology

regularizing_porosity.doc: phi_0 in notes; added to hydrology_englacial_porosity in pressure equation time derivative term

englacial_porosity.doc: phi in notes; macroporosity of englacial system, following [\ref Bartholomausetal2011]

lower_bound_creep_regularization.doc: Y_0 in notes; creep closure term in evolution of layer thickness remains positive (active) even at zero water if this is positive; in PISMDistributedHydrology

creep_closure_coefficient.doc: c_2 in notes; coefficient of creep closure term in evolution of layer thickness in PISMDistributedHydrology

cavitation_opening_coefficient.doc: c_1 in notes; coefficient of cavitation opening term in evolution of layer thickness in PISMDistributedHydrology

roughness_scale.doc: W_r in notes; roughness scale determining maximum amount of cavitation opening in PISMDistributedHydrology

potential_gradient_power_in_flux.doc: = beta in notes; power beta in Darcy's law q = - k W^alpha |grad psi|^{beta-2} grad psi, for subglacial water layer; used by PISMRoutingHydrology and PISMDistributedHydrology

thickness_power_in_flux.doc: = alpha in notes; power alpha in Darcy's law q = - k W^alpha |grad psi|^{beta-2} grad psi, for subglacial water layer; used by PISMRoutingHydrology and PISMDistributedHydrology

hydraulic_conductivity.doc: = k in notes; lateral conductivity, in Darcy's law, for subglacial water layer; units depend on powers alpha = hydrology_thickness_power_in_flux and beta = hydrology_potential_gradient_power_in_flux; used by PISMRoutingHydrology and PISMDistributedHydrology
hydraulic_conductivity.units: m^{2 beta - alpha} s^{2 beta - 3} kg^{1-beta}

bwat_diffusion_time.doc: diffusion time for melt water thickness; only used by hydrology model 'diffuseonly'=PISMDiffuseOnlyHydrology

bwat_diffusion_distance.doc: diffusion distance for melt water thickness; only used by hydrology model 'diffuseonly'=PISMDiffuseOnlyHydrology

bwat_decay_rate.doc: = 1 m per 1000 years; rate at which bwat is reduced to zero, in absence of other effects like basal melt rate and/or diffusion; used by PISMTillCanHydrology and derived models; not used by some hydrology models

bwat_max.doc: maximum thickness of the basal melt water layer; used by PISMTillCanHydrology and derived models; not used by some hydrology models

pressure_fraction.doc: water pressure is this fraction of overburden in PISMTillCanHydrology and derived models; water pressure is scaled by this fraction in PISMRoutingHydrology

const_bmelt.doc: = 1 cm per year of melt; only used if hydrology_use_const_bmelt = 'yes'

use_const_bmelt.doc: if 'yes', subglacial hydrology model sees basal melt rate which is constant and given by hydrology_const_bmelt

model.doc: Choose the hydrology sub-model from 'tillcan', 'diffuseonly', 'routing', 'distributed'.  These models determine the evolution of the subglacial water layer thickness (bwat) and pressure (bwp).  Normally bwat affects the basal values of the internal energy (enthalpy or temperature) field, and bwat, bwp determine the strength of the subglacial layer (the basal shearstress).  The 'tillcan' model (default) does not move water laterally; roughly it is the undrained plastic till model of [\ref Tulaczyketal2000b].  The 'diffuseonly' model is documented in [\ref BBssasliding]; see equation (11).  Neither 'tillcan' nor 'diffuseonly' are mass-conserving.  The 'routing' model is a mass-conserving, minimal distributed subglacial hydrology model that directs water along the steepest descent route of the hydraulic potential, and where the pressure is a fixed fraction of overburden; this model is suitable for identifying locations of subglacial lakes.  The 'distributed' model is a mass-conserving, distributed subglacial hydrology model that models the physical opening and closing of linked cavities on an area averaged basis; pressure evolves nontrivially.  The 'routing' and 'distributed' models may make PISM run pretty slowly because of the fast time-scale for liquid water movement.

air_temp_all_precip_as_rain.doc: threshold temperature above which all precipitation is rain; must exceed air_temp_all_precip_as_snow to avoid division by zero, because difference is in a denominator

air_temp_all_precip_as_snow.doc: threshold temperature below which all precipitation is snow

refreeze_ice_melt.doc: If set, refreeze pdd_refreeze fraction of melted ice, otherwise all of the melted ice runs off.

balance_year_start_day.doc: day of year for October 1st, beginning of the balance year in northern latitudes.

fausto_beta_snow_c.doc: water-equivalent thickness; for formula (6) in [\ref Faustoetal2009]

fausto_beta_ice_c.doc: water-equivalent thickness; for formula (6) in [\ref Faustoetal2009]

fausto_beta_snow_w.doc: water-equivalent thickness; for formula (6) in [\ref Faustoetal2009]

fausto_beta_ice_w.doc: water-equivalent thickness; for formula (6) in [\ref Faustoetal2009]

fausto_latitude_beta_w.doc: latitude below which to use warm case, in formula (6) in [\ref Faustoetal2009]

std_dev_lapse_lat_rate.doc: std_dev is a function of latitude, with rate of change with respect to latitude given by this constant

std_dev_lapse_lat_base.doc: std_dev is a function of latitude, with value pdd_std_dev at this latitude; this value only active if pdd_std_dev_lapse_lat_rate is nonzero

std_dev.doc: std dev of daily temp variation; = EISMINT-Greenland value [\ref RitzEISMINT]

factor_ice.doc: EISMINT-Greenland value [\ref RitzEISMINT] ; = (8 mm liquid-water-equivalent) / (pos degree day)

factor_snow.doc: EISMINT-Greenland value [\ref RitzEISMINT] ; = (3 mm liquid-water-equivalent) / (pos degree day)

positive_threshold_temp.doc: temperature used to determine meaning of 'positive' degree day

max_evals_per_year.doc: maximum number of times the PDD scheme will ask for air temperature and precipitation to build location-dependent time series for computing (expected) number of positive degree days and snow accumulation; the default means the PDD uses weekly samples of the annual cycle; see also pdd_std_dev

yearly_cycle_july_day.doc: day of year for July 15; used in corrected formula (4) in [\ref Faustoetal2009]

precip_exponential_factor_for_temperatur.doc: = 0.169/2.4; in SeaRISE-Greenland formula for paleo-precipitation from present; a 7.3% change of precipitation rate for every one degC of temperature change [\ref Huybrechts02]

fausto.doc: Near-surface air temperature parameterization after Fausto et al

kappa_mj.doc: longitude-dependence coefficient for formula (2) in [\ref Faustoetal2009]

c_mj.doc: latitude-dependence coefficient for formula (2) in [\ref Faustoetal2009]

gamma_mj.doc: = -5.426 / 1km; mean slope lapse rate for formula (2) in [\ref Faustoetal2009]

d_mj.doc: = 14.70+273.15; base temperature for formula (2) in [\ref Faustoetal2009]

kappa_ma.doc: longitude-dependence coefficient for formula (1) in [\ref Faustoetal2009]

c_ma.doc: latitude-dependence coefficient for formula (1) in [\ref Faustoetal2009]

gamma_ma.doc: = -6.309 / 1km; mean slope lapse rate for formula (1) in [\ref Faustoetal2009]

d_ma.doc: = 41.83+273.15; base temperature for formula (1) in [\ref Faustoetal2009]

buffer_size.doc: number of 2D climate forcing records to keep in memory; = 5 years of monthly records

evaluations_per_year.doc: length of the time-series used to compute temporal averages of forcing data (such as mean annual temperature)

ocean_sub_shelf_heat_flux_into_ice.doc: = J m-2 s-1; naively chosen default value for heat from ocean; see comments in src/coupler/PISMOcean.cc

max_low_temp_count.doc: Maximum number of grid points with ice temperature below global_min_allowed_temp.

linear_in_temperature_heat_capacity.doc: If yes, use varcEnthalpyConverter class to convert (internally) temperature to/from enthalpy.  It is based on equation (4.39) in [\ref GreveBlatter2009].  Otherwise use default class EnthalpyConverter which has temperature-independent (i.e. constant) specific heat capacity, set by constant ice_specific_heat_capacity.

temperature_dependent_thermal_conductivi.doc: If yes, use varkenthSystemCtx class in the energy step. It is base on formula (4.37) in [\ref GreveBlatter2009]. Otherwise use enthSystemCtx, which has temperature-independent thermal conductivity set by constant ice_thermal_conductivity.

temperate_ice_tolerance.doc: tolerance to use when deciding if ice is temperate

reference_temperature.doc: reference temperature in the definition of enthalpy

cold_bulge_max.doc: = (2009 J kg-1 K-1) * (30 K); maximum amount by which advection can reduce the enthalpy of a column of ice below its surface enthalpy value

temperate_conductivity_ratio.doc: K in cold ice is multiplied by this fraction to give K0 in [\ref AschwandenBuelerKhroulevBlatter]

bedrock_thermal_layer.doc: model of the bedrock thermal layer

specific_heat_capacity.doc: for bedrock used in thermal model

thermal_conductivity.doc: for bedrock used in thermal model

density.doc: density of the thermal bedrock layer

target_water_fraction.doc: liquid water fraction (omega) above which drainage occurs, but below which there is no drainage; see [\ref AschwandenBuelerKhroulevBlatter]

max_rate.doc: = 0.05 year-1; maximum rate at which liquid water fraction in temperate ice could possibly drain; see [\ref AschwandenBuelerKhroulevBlatter]

defaults.doc: values to use when the corresponding NetCDF variable is not found

tillphi.doc: till friction angle value to use if variable tillphi is absent in bootstrapping file; tends not to slip

bmelt.doc: basal melt rate value to use if variable bmelt is absent in bootstrapping file

bwp.doc: basal water pressure value to use if variable bwp is absent in bootstrapping file; most hydrology models do not use this value because bwp is diagnostic

enwat.doc: effective englacial water thickness value to use if variable enwat is absent in bootstrapping file

bwat.doc: basal water thickness value to use if variable bwat is absent in bootstrapping file

uplift.doc: uplift value to use if dbdt variable is absent in bootstrapping file

geothermal_flux.doc: geothermal flux value to use if bheatflx variable is absent in bootstrapping file

medium.doc: list of variables to save with -o_size medium
medium.value: acab bwp cbar cbase csurf cflx climatic_mass_balance diffusivity ice_surface_temp mask schoofs_theta tauc taud_mag thksmooth topgsmooth usurf wvelsurf temp_pa liqfrac enthalpy IcebergMask edot_1 edot_2

big.doc: list of variables to save with -o_size medium
big.value: acab age bfrict bheatflx bmelt bwat bwp cbar cbase cell_area cflx climatic_mass_balance csurf dbdt diffusivity enthalpy enthalpybase enthalpysurf flux_divergence hardav ice_surface_temp lat liqfrac litho_temp lon mask ocean_kill_mask rank schoofs_theta tauc taud_mag temp tempbase tempsurf temp_pa temppabase tempicethk tempicethk_basal thk thksmooth tillphi topg topgsmooth velbase velsurf velbar usurf uvel vvel wvel wvel_rel wvelbase wvelsurf nuH

variable_order.doc: storage order to use for spatial variables

fill_value.doc: The value to use as a filler in ice-free areas.

correct_cell_areas.doc: Use the WGS84 datum to compute cell areas. Used to report volumes and areas

force_output_times.doc: Modify the time-stepping mechanism to hit times requested using -extra_times.
Modify the time-stepping mechanism to hit times requested using -ts_times.

buffer_size.doc: Number of scalar diagnostic time-series records to hold in memory before writing to disk. (PISM writes this many time-series records to reduce I/O costs.) Send the USR2 signal to flush time-series.

summary_time_units.doc: time units to use in stdout reporting

area.doc: an integer; log base 10 of scale factor to use for area (in km^2) in summary line to stdout

volume.doc: an integer; log base 10 of scale factor to use for volume (in km^3) in summary line to stdout

dimension_name.doc: name of the time NetCDF variable in input and output files

reference_date.doc: reference date to use in output PISM files

part_redist.doc: for partially filled grid cell scheme, redistribute residuals Hresidual

part_grid.doc: apply partially filled grid cell scheme

kill_icebergs.doc: identify and kill detached ice-shelf areas

surface_gradient_method.doc: surface gradient computation method used by the SIA stress balance model

mask.doc: parameters related to the cell type mask

dry_simulation.doc: If set the ice is always considered grounded

floating_thickness_standard.doc: If flotation criterion is different by more than this amount then mask is set to MASK_ICE_FREE_OCEAN or MASK_FLOATING.

ice_free_thickness_standard.doc: If ice is thinner than this standard then the mask is set to MASK_ICE_FREE_BEDROCK or MASK_ICE_FREE_OCEAN.

adaptive_timestepping_ratio.doc: Adaptive time stepping ratio for the explicit scheme for the mass balance equation; \ref BBL, inequality (25)

skip.doc: Use the temperature, age, and SSA stress balance computation skipping mechanism.

max.doc: Number of mass-balance steps, including SIA diffusivity updates, to perform before a the temperature, age, and SSA stress balance computations are done

count.doc: If enabled, IceModel::run() will count the number of time steps it took.  Sometimes useful for performance evaluation.  Counts all steps, regardless of whether processes (mass continuity, energy, velocity, ...) occurred within the step.

tikhonov.doc: Parameters for the Tikhonov minimization problem

ptol.doc: threshold for reaching desired misfit for adaptive Tikhonov algorithms

rtol.doc: relative threshold for Tikhonov stopping criterion

atol.doc: absolute threshold for Tikhonov stopping criterion

target_misfit.doc: desired root misfit for SSA inversions

hardav_max.doc: Maximum allowed value of hardav for inversions with bound constraints

hardav_min.doc: Minimum allowed value of hardav for inversions with bound constraints

tauc_max.doc: Maximum allowed value of tauc for inversions with bound constraints

tauc_min.doc: Minimum allowed value of tauc for inversions with bound constraints

length_scale.doc: typical length scale for rescaling derivative norms

velocity_eps.doc: tiny size of ice velocities during inversion

velocity_scale.doc: typical size of ice velocities expected during inversion

design_cH1.doc: weight of derivative part of an H1 norm for inversion design variables

design_cL2.doc: weight of derivative-free part of an H1 norm for inversion design variables

design_func.doc: functional used for inversion design variables

state_func.doc: functional used for inversion design variables

design_param.doc: Parameters of design variables used during inversion
parameterization of design variables used during inversion

trunc_hardav0.doc: transition point of change to linear behaviour for design variable parameterization type 'trunc'

hardav_eps.doc: tiny hardav used as a substitute for 0 in some tauc parameterizations

trunc_tauc0.doc: transition point of change to linear behaviour for design variable parameterization type 'trunc'

tauc_eps.doc: tiny yield stress used as a substitute for 0 in some tauc parameterizations

method.doc: algorithm to use for SSA inversions
